body: Could you provide a simple app demonstrating the issue ?

Yeah, here you go: https://github.com/ccnokes/electron-did-fail-load. 

I was able to verify that behavior in 0.36.9 (my version) and the latest 0.37.6. My sample app is on the latest. 

I based it on electron-boilerplate so it's got all of that project's commit history on it, but here's my change set: 
https://github.com/ccnokes/electron-did-fail-load/commit/ce7f3a6d18615cbbf20bc09132bc81f58b7f0496

After `npm install`ing it, run `node server.js` to start a node server that will serve a gif to download. Then start the electron app with `npm run build && npm run start`. Click the "download gif" link to see the behavior I'm talking about. Electron should emit a `did-fail-load` event with a `-3` code, and then crash once the native save file dialog is closed. 

If it's helpful, I can try to PR a failing unit test for this. I wish I could jump in and debug it more but I don't really know C++ or ObjC ðŸ˜¦ .

Thanks for the test case, the `did-fail-load` is just a duplicate fire of `did-fail-provisional-load`, i think we should separate `did-fail-provisional-load` and `did-fail-load` since its causing confusion @zcbenz ? The crash stack trace


> As a side note, I was calling loadURL in the did-fail-load handler which caused Electron to crash. I can provide the full dump for that if you'd like.

<del>The crash had been fixed in 0.37.x.</del>

EDIT: Sorry, it seems to be a new crash.

> i think we should separate did-fail-provisional-load and did-fail-load since its causing confusion

It would be a breaking change, #1242.
If the url is a file download ONLY "did-fail-provisional-load" is emitted. "did-fail-load" NOT anymore!
